message: Repealing the ACA would not only mean over 23 million people will lose health insurance, but it will cost millions of jobs. In Oregon alone, 45,000 jobs would be lost. I remain committed to standing up to any attempt to repeal the ACA. http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/news/2017/01/09/obamacare-repeal-in-oregon-huge-job-losses-more.html

If you’re worried about how a repeal of the ACA could impact you, your family, your job or your business, I want to hear from you. Follow this link to share your story with me on how the ACA has helped you, or how repealing could hurt you: https://schrader.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=3142
I stand against any attempt to repeal the ACA because no one should have to go into debt to stay healthy.

Donald Trump said yesterday that he would be "the greatest jobs producer that God ever created." Give me a break. If Congress follows through with his plan to repeal the ACA, we will lose 45,000 jobs in Oregon and millions more across the country. I spoke on the House floor today about how we can't afford this disastrous repeal policy. Watch here:   https://youtu.be/4VNPHoSeZBY

I’m always looking for ways I can work across the aisle because getting things done for you guys at home is my number one priority. But an outright repeal of the ACA is just reckless. I sent a letter to Speaker Ryan today expressing ways where we could work to make improvements on the ACA. I refuse to support this Trump agenda to get rid of health care for millions of people. Read my letter here: http://schrader.house.gov/UploadedFiles/New_Dem_ACA_Letter.pdf
I was proud to participate in today's United For Immigrant Rights Rally at the State Capitol.

Thank you to the students in Ms. Niedermeyer and Mr. Brown’s social studies classes at North Salem High School for your thoughtful letters regarding your concerns about the future of immigration reform in this country. Passing comprehensive immigration reform is critical for the health and safety of students and families in this district and across the country. Your engagement on these issues is an inspiration and an encouragement to me, and I look forward to watching your role as leaders grows in this community.

Today I had the opportunity to be part of the launch of Oregon HUB. The vision of Matt Maletis and Josh Veentjer, this revolutionary campus and incubator will provide the space for our premier cannabis businesses to research, innovate and distribute their products—all from one location. This new cannabis industry is quickly taking shape here in Oregon, already contributing to a thriving economy with jobs and revenue that benefit cities, counties and the state. I'm looking forward to what this project will produce!

Today, my Democratic colleagues and I sent a letter to President-elect Trump to express our deep concern about how his presidency will affect women and girls. We wrote him that his "actions - not words - will demonstrate your willingness to advance positive policies for women." You can read our letter here: http://schrader.house.gov/uploadedfiles/pcc_letter_to_pe_trump.pdf
Tune in now as I join Maggie and Carl for a half an hour on KPAM News Talk 860 to talk about the new Congress.

This is a friendly reminder that Tuesday, January 31 is the last day for open enrollment in the Health Insurance Marketplace. Visit healthcare.gov or see a local health insurance agent to learn about your health insurance options, enroll in a plan for the first time, or change your plan.

Yesterday, the President signed an Executive Order to freeze federal hiring for at least 90 days, including at the VA. One in twelve Oregonians is a veteran, and about one fifth of our vets has a service related disability. That’s a lot of people who need and deserve treatment. While I’m always looking for ways to be fiscally responsible, it disturbs me that the President thinks that doing anything to prevent our veterans from receiving necessary care is in anyone’s best interest. That's why today I introduced a bill to prohibit any hiring freeze from specifically affecting the VA. Limiting availability of care is an absolutely unacceptable way to treat the men and women who have risked life and limb in the service of our country. http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390702

Had a great meeting with a group of high school students from my hometown, Canby. We packed everyone into my office had some good discussions on immigration, education and some of the biggest issues facing Oregon.

This morning I had the honor to join the Oregon National Guard - Oregon Military Department G/1-189th Aviation Regiment at their mobilization ceremony. This medical evacuation helicopter unit has been critical to rescue and fire suppression efforts at home and we wish them the best during their deployment abroad. Thank you for your service.
Tune in now as I join Mark Mason on News Radio 1190 KEX live at 2:30! https://goo.gl/TThv5j

Unbelievable! For President Trump to unilaterally stop visas for 90 days and refugees fleeing persecution, murder and rape for 120 days without cause, due process or justification goes against everything we hold dear in the Constitution. He has absolutely no respect for or understanding of the democratic republic he supposedly represents. It is time for Congress, the constitutional lawmaking body, to assert itself. This is dangerous to our own liberty.

Few organizations have the ability to bring a community together like Habitat for Humanity. This home, built through Habitat For Humanity Mid Willamette Valley's “Heroes With Heart” Veteran Build Program, was constructed with the help of volunteer veterans who donated their time and money to help put a roof over one Salem family’s head. Thank you to Habitat for Humanity, their partners, and these veterans who have sacrificed at home and abroad to make our communities a better place.

It’s ridiculous that our Director of National Intelligence and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff have been uninvited to principals committee meetings on our national security, while Steven Bannon, a person whose role in the administration is political, has a seat at the table. I signed onto a bill today to keep strictly political actors out of our National Security Council meetings, and make sure that our best on defense receive a standing invitation to meetings. Our national security is absolutely not a place for this kind of partisan nonsense.

I'll be hosting a Telephone Town Hall next week on Wednesday, February 15th at 6pm PT. This is a great opportunity for you to share your concerns and ideas with me without having to leave your home. On the day and time of the tele-town hall, my office will call the number that you provide and connect you to our telephone forum. Sign-up to participate here: https://schrader.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=3140

I spent the morning meeting with and hearing from leaders across Polk and Marion Counties. We discussed the necessity of ensuring that our children have access to a good education, the need for improvements to and funding for our aging infrastructure, and ways to bring the benefits of our rebounding economy to rural Oregonians. Thank you to all who attended for working with me in the service of our communities.

Thank you to the local leaders of Clackamas County for coming together to talk with me this morning. We had great conversations about supporting our local schools, improving our transportation systems, and driving economic development here in Clackamas County. Your advice on how I can best service this community is invaluable to me in Congress, and I thank you for your time and input.

Proud to co-chair the Paper and Packaging Caucus this congress with my friend, Congressman Bruce Poliquin (R-ME) to educate our colleagues about how valuable the paper and packaging industry is, not only in our home state, but throughout the entire country. Together we'll work to find the solutions needed to promote and grow this renewable and sustainable industry in our rural communities.
Wishing our beautiful home a happy 158th birthday today!
The mere idea of using our National Guard like this is outrageous & serves only to tear families apart & destroy American businesses.
Don’t miss our Clackamas County town hall tonight at Alder Creek Middle School. RSVP here to let us know that you’re coming!

Teaching our children how the United States government works, and how essential they are to its function, is key to maintaining a strong democracy in this country. Thank you to the AP US Government and Politics students at Oregon City High School for allowing me to come talk today during a difficult time in your community. Meeting with you gives me hope for our future.

I want to thank the local Archdiocese of Portland for their support of comprehensive immigration reform, and for all that they have done to care for refugees of all creeds and nations. It was a pleasure meeting with you today.

Participation is a critical to the healthy functioning of our democracy, and while there are many things in this country that I believe are on the wrong track, it was reassuring tonight to see more than 650 people show up, get involved and make their voice heard. I'd like to thank all of the Clackamas County residents who attended my town hall to tell me about what matters to them here at home and how they feel about how things are going in Washington.  Keeping an open conversation is one of my top priorities as your representative.

It is so important that our schools offer opportunities for students to get the training they need to become leaders in the future of STEM business and industry here in Oregon. Thank you to Portland Metro STEM Partnership for giving our children the option to follow the path that inspires them.
Don’t miss our Salem-area town hall tonight at North Salem High School. RSVP here to let us know that you’re coming!

Great meeting with the Oregon Industrial Hemp Farmers Association today. Thank you for your help paving the way for hemp research pilot programs in Oregon. Because of you, we are now poised to seize on this huge agricultural opportunity for our state and the country.

This administration keeps pushing policies of discrimination and hate ahead of anything else when we have actual issues to tackle and problems to fix. This backwards act serves zero purpose whatsoever. I'm proud that Oregon has always been at the forefront of inclusivity and acceptance, and I stand with the LGBTQ community. This is absurd.

During times like these it is so important that people stand up to get involved in our democracy. I was humbled by the number of people from Marion and Polk counties who came to my town hall tonight to express their feelings on how Washington is working, and their desire to help move this country forward. Thank you for stepping up to make your voices heard.

SAM Medical is just one of the many national defense and security industries and small businesses located here in Oregon. I was happy to tour their remarkable facility which also hosted today’s Pacific Northwest Defense Coalition (PNDC) roundtable. Thank you to SAM Medical and the PNDC for working hard to ensure that these businesses continue to bring a wide variety of jobs and economic opportunities to our community.
Don’t miss me on KGW-TV Straight Talk with Laurel Porter this Saturday at 4:30pm, or Sunday at 6:30pm.
In case you missed it, check out my interview on KGW-TV's Straight Talk with Laurel Porter from this past weekend.

I went into tonight hoping to hear a concrete vision that both Democrats and Republicans could rally behind. But all I heard were continued vague promises, campaign style one-liners and outright lies about our country. He claimed he’s ‘drained the swamp’ by putting Wall Street executives and his own children into advisor roles and cabinet positions. He lied and fear mongered around immigration. And his promises for Medicaid completely contradict the plan he currently supports. I refuse to give up hope that this Congress and this Presidency will find common ground on something. But I do have serious concerns that even on infrastructure and tax reform, two areas where we should be able to work together, his plans lacked any substance and fell short. We are five weeks into this Presidency and all we’ve gotten is mom and apple pie principles without any meat. Perhaps the tagline of the speech tonight should’ve been ‘where’s the beef?’

Always a pleasure seeing Planned Parenthood Advocates of Oregon. Thanks to Gnora and Jodi for coming all the way to DC to keep us updated in Congress on the incredibly important work Planned Parenthood is doing. Keep up the great work!

I'll be joining Mark Mason on KEX Radio at 2pm PT to talk about ACA repeal, my bill to lower drug costs, and my call for Jeff Sessions resignation. Tune into 1190 AM or listen online here: http://1190kex.iheart.com/

Congratulations to North Clackamas school district and to Superintendent Matt Utterback! It goes without saying our students are the future, and making sure our kids get a good education is so important. I'm incredibly proud of you guys, keep up the great work!

Today, I reintroduced my Department of Defense Overhead Cost Savings and Transparency Act to declassify the covered up Pentagon report showing $125 billion in administrative waste that could be saved or better spent. Just a few days ago the President proposed adding $54 billion more to our defense spending when we already have $125 billion in the Pentagon’s budget that can be spent more resourcefully. In addition to releasing the entire report, my bill would expedite consideration of legislation to implement the report’s recommendations to cut or reallocate the excess in spending, making sure our troops are well supplied to serve our country and keep us safe. http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390731
Don’t miss our Woodburn town hall with Oregon State Representative Teresa Alonso Leon this weekend at Valor Middle School. RSVP here to let us know that you’re coming!

Every year it is my honor and privilege to nominate Oregon’s brightest students to our Military Service Academies. With this event, I hope to give all students who have the motivation to become a commissioned officer in the United States military the opportunity to get the education and training they need to achieve their ambitions. Thank you to all the students and their families who attended.

Thank you to everyone who came from the Woodburn area to this weekend's town hall, hosted with Oregon State Representative Teresa Alonso Leon. It has been encouraging to me to see so many who have gotten involved and stayed engaged with the system this year, often for the first time. At these events, I’ve spoken with many of you about your concern over federal immigration policies, and I hear you. Oregon will not turn its back on our immigrant communities or our rural farming communities, and neither will I.
Less than 48 hours after receiving the Republican Repeal bill, my Energy & Commerce Committee is already marking it up. I went live from Committee with my opening statement:
We're live again from my Energy & Commerce Committee's markup of the Republican Repeal bill. Listen in:

After more than 27 hours in markup, the Republicans on my Energy & Commerce Committee pushed through their bill to repeal a fully funded Affordable Care Act and replace it with an unsustainable federal program that will shift costs to the states. And we still haven't seen any reports showing what the bill's real world effect will be on our pocket books, our economy, and our health care - something the Committee had before voting on the ACA in 2009.  My number one question about this bill: where's the beef?

The report that was released today confirms that the Republican repeal bill does not give people freedom, it backs them into a corner and forces them to choose between their health and their retirement. It forces them to choose whether to pay for health coverage or put food on the table. It forces them to choose between health coverage and a roof over their head. This plan means millions will be paying more for less quality care and less coverage, and I will not be supporting it. http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390746

Today is National #AgDay, a day to recognize our hard working farmers across Oregon who are the backbone of many of our local economies. I know firsthand what it takes for local family farms to raise and grow premium products that are enjoyed all around the world. On my farm in Canby, I grew organic strawberries, and today my son grows premium hops. Our Ag communities in Oregon depend on funding for research to be able to innovate and improve farm practices, and funding for food safety. But right now, the USDA is facing steep budget cuts under Trump’s budget proposal, and one of the top cabinet positions - the USDA Secretary - remains vacant. Across our district, we know farming isn’t just a job but a way of life. I wish a happy National #AgDay & #AgWeek to all of our farmers and farming communities in Oregon – I will continue to fight for you!

Just two short weeks after my Energy & Commerce Committee's marathon markup of the Republican repeal bill, we're already voting on it. I refuse to allow this bill to pass and strip health care away from hundreds of thousands of Oregonians and 24 million Americans. Watch along here as we debate the bill ahead of the vote:

Disease doesn’t care whether you live in a red state or a blue state. Illness doesn’t care whether you’re a Democrat or a Republican. Donald Trump said last night that he’s ready to move on from repeal if this fails. Well, I am too. I'm voting NO on this bill, and urge my colleagues to do so also.
Don't miss our Tillamook town hall tomorrow at the Tillamook High School Auditorium. RSVP here to let us know that you're coming!
Don't miss our Lincoln County town hall tomorrow at the Newport High School Gym. RSVP here to let us know that you're coming!

Thanks to everyone in Tillamook County who took the time to attend my town hall this morning, and especially Summer who came out for her first town hall today! This community has a history of working together to solve problems and I appreciate everyone who came out to talk to me about how I can continue that tradition for you in Washington.

It was great seeing everyone from Lincoln County who came out to attend my town hall this afternoon. I’m proud to represent this community where NOAA conducts cutting-edge ocean and climate science, where students receive a world-class education from Oregon Sea Grant, and where men and women of the United States Coast Guard have protected local fishermen and recreationalists for more than a century.  These are all programs that are integral to this community and the country, and I will not turn my back on the fight to protect them.

I’ve been receiving a lot of calls from folks back home asking how I will be voting SJ Res 34, a resolution that would overturn a rule on FCC internet privacy protections. I appreciate the feedback and engagement – it’s very encouraging. I will be voting NO on this bill. It goes without saying that your internet service provider should have your permission before using your data for commercial purposes. No one should have the right to use your information without your approval.
Thanks to Planned Parenthood Advocates of Oregon for stopping by today! So many women and men rely on Planned Parenthood's services and I'm always proud to #StandWithPP. #PinkOut

Something is very clearly wrong in our Portland VA, and we needed an investigation yesterday. Right now, the Portland VA has kicked more veterans out of the Caregiver Program for unidentified reasons than anywhere else in the country. In no way does this reflect Oregon or Oregon values. After giving us so much, our veterans deserve so much better than this. That's why I'm calling on the Portland VA to stop removing Oregon’s veterans immediately from the Caregiver Program until we have clear answers.  http://www.oregonlive.com/watchdog/index.ssf/2017/03/schrader_to_va_stop_kicking_ou.html
Good luck tonight Oregon! #GoDucks

Assad has shown himself to be a brutal authoritarian with zero compassion or respect for his own people much less any other nation and its imperative he be removed from power. I do have serious misgivings about any further authorization without involving leadership from our EU and Middle East allies. And I am totally opposed to any President taking military action without consideration and approval from Congress. Read my full statement about the US airstrike on Syria here:  http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390756

I sent a letter to the VA last week, along with your entire Oregon Democratic delegation, calling for an investigation into the Caregiver Program at the Portland VA to find out why our veterans in Portland, like Aaron, are getting kicked off of the program at such a significantly higher rate than nationally. Our veterans deserve so much better than this, and we all deserve answers. We're also calling on the VA to immediately stop removals from the program in Portland’s jurisdiction. You can read our letter, along with a list of specific questions we have for the VA here: http://bit.ly/2nW3vHB

Very pleased that the VA has heard the concerns we laid out in our letter calling on them to immediately stop removing veterans from the Portland Caregiver Program. We and our veterans need assurance that they are being treated fairly, and not being held to a different standard than veterans across the country.  http://www.oregonlive.com/watchdog/index.ssf/2017/04/portland_va_to_temporarily_sto.html#incart_river_home

Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler and I have been working with our states, tribes, and local communities for several years now on solutions to save our endangered salmon and other native fish in the Columbia River system. Last week we introduced a bill that provides tribal members and government fish managers with the means to remove predatory California sea lions from specific areas where they are posing the most harm. These predators are present in numbers totally inconsistent with their historic range. Our bill will help eliminate this threat to our iconic Oregon salmon that are struggling to survive once and for all.

Be sure to "Like" your favorite piece by the talented high school art students in Oregon's Fifth Congressional District. This year for our Congressional Art Competition, we would like to offer the opportunity for our constituents to vote on their favorite piece. Check out the amazing work, "Like" your favorite, and "Share" on your own Facebook to spread the word. The submission that receives the most likes by Monday, April 24th will receive our first ever People's Choice Award!

Over a week ago, I sent a letter to Sec. Shulkin calling on the VA to immediately stop removing veterans from the Portland Caregiver Program, and I’m very pleased that the VA heard my concerns then, and that they've now expanded that to veterans nationwide. Our veterans deserve transparency which includes knowing exactly what standards they’re being held to. I’m looking forward to continuing to work with the VA to get the answers we need, to resolve these cases, and to ensure that our veterans are receiving the best and most appropriate care. http://www.oregonlive.com/watchdog/index.ssf/2017/04/va_stops_kicking_out_vets_from.html#incart_std

This week is #NationalParkWeek honoring our nation’s incredible and vast beauty. In 2016, 1.3 million people visited Oregon’s national parks. Celebrate this year by heading outside and visiting one of Oregon’s five national parks like Crater Lake. Admission is free this weekend to all national parks across the country.
Don't forget to "Like" your favorite piece for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition People's Choice Award! Voting ends Monday at noon.

Thank you to State Representative Teresa Alonso Leon, Woodburn Area Chamber of Commerce and Woodburn Downtown Association for helping to promote small local business in downtown Woodburn today. Together, we visited El Forastero Ropa Vaquera, a footwear company specializing in cowboy boots, Tienda Lucero, a local grocery store and local meat market Carniceria Jalisco. It’s important that we all support our local communities and encourage folks to get out there and discover what great things their local businesses have to offer.

Voting has closed on the "People's Choice Award" for our 2017 Congressional Art Competition. Congratulations to Lakeridge High’s Claire Schlagenhaft for her piece, “Whisper,” with 142 likes as of noon today! Thank you to everyone for your participation and your enthusiasm for our young artists.

Thank you to all the high school art students who submitted work to our 2017 Congressional Art Competition! I want to congratulate Lake Oswego High School’s Tuesday Lewman as the winner with “The Dynamic Personality Behind the Brand.” This piece will represent the district in the Cannon passageway to the Capitol Building alongside the winners from each congressional district in the country. I also want to congratulate 1st runner up Sasha Hennig with “Gauche,” 2nd runner up Wooyeon Kim with “Childhood Memories,” 3rd runner up Alexandra Lyon with “Royals,” and first ever People Choice Award winner Claire Schlagenhaft for her piece, “Whisper.”
Even as a veterinarian of 30+ years, meeting new puppies never gets old! Thanks to the Humane Rescue Alliance for stopping by the office with six-week-old Oregon and his brother, Indiana, today!
I'll be joining Mark Mason shortly on News Radio 1190 KEX. Tune in! http://1190kex.iheart.com/

Had a great discussion here at the Capitol with a few dozen students from Inza Wood Middle School in Wilsonville this afternoon. They came well prepared with some very impressive questions. Stay curious and keep up the great work at school!

Despite marriage equality, 63% of LGBT Americans still face discrimination in their daily lives. And today, the President is expected to sign an order that will allow for even more discrimination. I’ve always been proud of Oregon for being at the forefront of equal rights, and I’m proud today to continue to fight for those values by cosponsoring the Equality Act. This bill will ensure that LGBT Americans have the same protections that are already in place for other Americans, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.
I was a NO in March and I am a NO today on the Republican attempt to repeal Obamacare. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7OAsOqgdwXs

I’m at a loss for words, frankly. This is a bad piece of legislation that is going to strip healthcare from 400,000 Oregonians and millions of Americans, dramatically hike up premiums for everyone, and cost taxpayers everywhere more money. Not to mention it cuts one of the most important pieces of Obamacare: protections for people with pre-existing conditions. Today, political rhetoric trumped what’s best for the American people.  http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390763

I really appreciate all of the students from Woodburn High School who took the time to speak with me today. I’m always impressed by how engaged and informed our students are in Oregon. We had an important conversation about the current direction of immigration policies, recent ICE tactics, and the future of DACA protection. These policies have a huge impact on our families, our neighbors and our communities. Oregon isn't going to turn its back on our immigrant community, and neither will I.

To effectively serve as your representative I believe that it is important to keep open communication with local leadership. Today, I met with Tillamook County leaders to talk about the issues that they are most concerned about at home. We talked about many things from the restoration of the Tillamook Bay Jetty to concerns about National Flood Insurance Plans. I will continue to work hard in Congress to support the needs of this community.

Tillamook Rotarians are out there doing great work every day, raising money to help kids from Tillamook High School afford to pursue their college dreams. Thanks for doing all you do and for having me speak with you today. Tillamook Rotary Club

Comey should have been fired months ago after his unprofessional involvement in handling the Clinton emails in the last election. Now that he is investigating the relationship between the administration and documented Russian interference in the election, Trump fires him. C'mon man. We needed a special prosecutor yesterday.

From the cutting-edge research done at NOAA to the fishermen on the water, Lincoln County is deeply integrated with the federal government. Yesterday, I met with local leaders to talk about the issues that the community faces and solutions I can work towards in Congress. I talked to many of you who were concerned that cuts to agencies like NOAA and the Coast Guard will put our communities, industries, and citizens in jeopardy, and I want you to know that I will not stop fighting for you.

This morning Pacific Seafood showed me their plans to revitalize a neglected plot on the Newport waterfront. Plans include a new ice-house, small business incubators, and a state-of-the-art processing facility. I look forward to seeing the project progress and how it will help local businesses and our fishing community.

Fishing has been the backbone of our Oregon Coast communities for as long as people have lived along the coast. Today, we operate what is arguably one of the most sustainable fisheries in the world. But, challenges remain for this industry to sustain itself. Every year I meet with local fishermen and representatives to talk about what I can do in Congress to help them to continue to succeed and grow. This sustainable industry is an anchor to our coastal communities and I will remain a committed advocate for it in Congress.

Happy to join the Rotary Club of Clackamas Clackamas Rotary today. The Rotary motto is, “Service Above Self” and this club does that in spades. Thank you for your recent community service helping a local student go to college and supporting local Habitat for Humanity.

Honored to dedicate Canby High School’s new prescription drug disposal box. With the help of Dave's Prescription Shop, the first pharmacy in Clackamas County to host a kiosk like this, Lines for Life, and the Oregon Coalition for Responsible Use of Meds, the students of Canby’s Student Health Advisory Board have now made a key component of their “Talk About it” campaign a reality. It is dangerous to ignore the opioid epidemic that grips communities throughout the country, and I am proud of these students working to raise awareness of prescription drug abuse and suicide prevention.  These projects that allow folks to safely dispose of medication and start a conversation about this issue are essential to the fight.

The other day I got a handwritten letter from Cloie, a Canby fifth-grader, telling me that she is concerned with a new law that allows so-called hunters in Alaska to shoot animals from helicopters and kill wolves while sleeping in their dens. As a veterinarian and a sportsman myself, I think these practices are despicable, and I don't know anybody who calls themselves a sportsman who doesn't agree. That is why I voted against this resolution in Congress. Thank you for sharing your opinion, Cloie, I want to hear more from you in the future!

I’m very pleased that a bipartisan bill I cosponsored to improve our career and technical education programs passed unanimously out of the Education and Workforce Committee today. The bill will support innovative CTE learning opportunities that align with in-demand jobs, helping students gain the skills they need to succeed in today’s job market. It’s disappointingly ironic though that members of Congress from both sides of the aisle came together to improve access to better education on the same day that reports leaked that the President plans to slash billions of dollars from our education budget, including a 15% cut to CTE education. Without access to a good education and to programs that prepare our kids with those in-demand skills, the next generation won’t be able to compete in the global economy. https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/trumps-first-full-education-budget-deep-cuts-to-public-school-programs-in-pursuit-of-school-choice/2017/05/17/2a25a2cc-3a41-11e7-8854-21f359183e8c_story.html?tid=ss_tw&utm_term=.7efcdc662cc0

The same day that Trump released his reckless budget proposal that slashes billions of dollars from programs that benefit our veterans, I’ve introduced a bill to protect veterans & servicemembers from home foreclosures while they are serving our country overseas. It is currently, and rightfully, illegal for a mortgage loan lender to foreclose on an active duty servicemember. You may have read recently about Jacob McGreevey, a veteran from Vancouver, who’s home was illegally foreclosed on in 2012 while he was serving his third of four tours of duty. Jacob didn’t know his rights at the time and by the time he learned about protections that made the foreclosure illegal, a court ruled against him, claiming too much time had passed. My HOMES Act is a simple, no-brainer bill to protect our fighting men and women, like Jacob, from exploitation by unscrupulous mortgage loan lenders. Our servicemen and women have earned certain basic benefits like knowing that their families and their homes are taken care of while they are overseas. http://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390765

Memorial Day is a day that we as a nation set aside to remember the millions of service members who fought and died, defending our freedoms and way of life. Today we honor and console the families of those brave men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice. And we keep in our prayers every Marine, Soldier, Airman, Sailor and Coast Guardsman and ask that they be able come home to their families. On this Memorial Day I want to thank all of our veterans and their families for their service to our nation.  May God bless you, your families, our great State of Oregon and God bless the United States of America.

As Oregonians, we have immense pride in our long history of being inclusive and accepting of all people. I am deeply disturbed by the hate crime that occurred on the MAX train this weekend. There is absolutely no time and no place for hate of any kind. My thoughts this weekend are with the families of the brave men who ultimately gave their lives to defend and protect our values and stand against the worst, ugliest kind of hate.

The Paris climate agreement is an important step towards reducing the global effects of climate change that every country in the world (with the exception of only Syria and Nicaragua) took last year. Joining only two other countries in rejecting the agreement is not in the US’s best interest strategically or economically and it represents a serious abdication of our responsibility as a world super power to lead by example. Here are some quick facts, in case you didn’t know, about the agreement:

We’ve just taken a monumental step backwards when we should be stepping up and setting an example of leadership for the rest of world. The US is joining only two other countries in the world – Syria and Nicaragua – in rejecting the Paris climate agreement. The uncertainty alone that the President has been building has already caused allied leaders to question our dependability. And now it isn’t just with our allies, but with the entire world that we’re creating an atmosphere of ambiguity. We’ve just abdicated a very serious responsibility to lead the world in curbing the effects of climate change. The implications this has for our entire world is disturbing.

I will be hosting a Telephone Town Hall on Wednesday, June 14th at 6pm PT. To participate, please follow the link and sign-up. At the time of the town hall, we will give you a call at the phone number you provide. This is a great opportunity for you to share your concerns and ideas with me without having to leave your home. I'm looking forward to hearing from you! https://schrader.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=3143

You probably tuned in at some point today to the Senate hearing with former FBI Director Comey, but over on the House side, we spent the day fighting to protect the Dodd-Frank legislation that reins in the big banks on Wall Street. As a small business owner, I believe DC should be in the business of producing outcomes rather than micromanaging with bureaucratic rules and regulations. But Dodd-Frank is a good piece of legislation that’s been necessary in preventing another financial catastrophe like the one we saw in 2008. Millions lost their homes and jobs while retirement savings evaporated into nothingness. Dodd-Frank ensured that banks would be less likely to go broke, less likely to need bailing out, and less likely to wreak havoc on our global economy. The so-called CHOICE Act that I voted against today will not only allow the big banks to go back to mixing your deposits with their risky investments, but it also weakens capital requirements, making those big banks vulnerable again. Not to mention, the bill goes too far in loosening credit requirements and increases the likelihood of risky derivative investments, putting us exactly back to where we were prior to the Great Recession. Our focus should be on easing up government bureaucracy on our community banks and credit unions who were never part of the problem. This financially irresponsible bill does none of that.

Yesterday, I had the privilege of welcoming WWII veterans from our 5th district in Oregon out to Washington, D.C. They were here with Honor Flight of Portland Oregon and spent their time visiting the Capitol Building, our war memorials, and many of the other monuments in our nation's capitol. Thank you to all of our veterans and their families for the sacrifices you make for our country. And thank you to Honor Flight for all of your hard work in creating such a special and deserved program for our veterans. Meeting with some of our vets was a great way to end out this week.

Don't forget to sign up for my Telephone Town Hall tomorrow, June 14th at 6pm PT. The deadline to signup is today at noon PT. To participate, please follow the link and sign-up. At the time of the town hall, we will give you a call at the phone number you provide. This is a great opportunity for you to share your concerns and ideas with me without having to leave your home. Looking forward to hearing from you! https://schrader.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=3143
Great conversation with the hardworking men and women of the Northwest Oregon Labor Council this morning.
Tune in to Portland’s KEX 1190 now to hear me talk with Mark Mason about everything going on in DC. http://1190kex.iheart.com/

Mental health issues are often tragically untreated, especially in our kids. The Providence Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Unit at Providence Willamette Falls Hospital in Oregon City is trying to do something about it by opening the first inpatient psychiatric unit for children and teens in Oregon. Thanks to Providence for helping to support our families.

Thank you to the Three Rivers VFW Post 1324 for having me yesterday evening to talk with local veterans about the issues that they see in their community. I look forward to continuing to work with you on these issues in Washington.

My bill to prevent wildfires and blackouts passed in the House with overwhelming bipartisan support today. The bill will provide utility companies with a streamlined and consistent process for being able to fulfill their mandated responsibility to keep our communities safe by removing hazardous trees and plants around transmission lines before they cause costly and deadly damage. Creating this streamlined process will save everyone money, and frankly a lot of heartache. This bill is a great example of the bipartisan work this Congress can achieve for everyone back at home when we put common sense ahead of politics and work together.

On June 26th in 2003, 2013 & 2015, we saw incredible victories for the LGBT community. Oregon has long been a leader in fighting for equality for everyone and I'm proud today to stand up for our Oregon values by cosponsoring a resolution in celebration of this landmark day!
Whether it’s in the Senate or the House, repealing Obamacare is still bad for our health, bad for our economy, and will cost taxpayers everywhere even more money.

Over the last few weeks, I've been leading a group of my Democratic colleagues from around the country to come up with real solutions to stabilize the individual health insurance market and improve Obamacare, while protecting all of it's great pieces. We released our plan this morning. The Affordable Care Act has helped 20 million Americans access quality health care. Medicaid expansion has been an unqualified success in both red and blue states. Let's get one thing clear: repeal is not a solution. But we have to face facts. Some folks in the individual marketplace have seen their premiums and deductibles increase significantly due to an imbalance in the marketplace and uncertainty caused by this new administration. Let’s fix that! Our five-point proposal aims squarely at stabilizing and improving the individual market. We’ve talked with health care experts, providers, and patients to find real solutions. If we are serious about making health care affordable for everyone, it's time we direct our focus there. Read about my plan here:  https://schrader.house.gov/solutions-over-politics/

It was great meeting Julia Trachsel who will be a senior at Siletz next year. Julia is in DC this week participating in the Washington Journalism and Media Conference.  I always enjoy the opportunity to meet smart engaged students from home. I know we'll see great things from Julia in the future!

Two weeks ago, I led nine of my colleagues from across the Democratic caucus to propose Solution Over Politics, a plan to stabilize and improve the individual market while protecting the Affordable Care Act. And I'm pleased that today, 79 more of our colleagues joined us in support of our proposals. Together, we called on Speaker Paul Ryan to lead in a bipartisan manner on health care. Senate Republicans have indicated a willingness to work with Democrats on stabilizing the individual market. Here in the House, we are ready to work together too. https://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390898

Next week, we'll have the rare opportunity at home in Oregon to see a total solar eclipse. Check out ahead of time what the eclipse will look like in your area! https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/7/25/16019892/solar-eclipse-2017-interactive-map

I voted for legislation today imposing new sanctions on North Korea, Russia, and Iran and was pleased to see such overwhelming bipartisan support for the bill. These countries have shown continuous disregard for international norms. I’m proud that my colleagues in the House stood side-by-side today to hold these countries accountable.

Today I had the pleasure of touring Molalla’s downtown to visit  PepCo Designs, Central Coast Medical Billing Services, and  Clinkscales Portable Toilets & Septic Service LLC. I’m happy to see this community growing with business who never let an opportunity down the drain.

The Lake Oswego Rotary Club is a group that brings the community together regardless of culture, race, creed, and politics. I appreciate them bringing me into that community today to talk about the work being done in Washington.

Today I led a bipartisan group to release a plan to improve our health care system to provide some predictability as insurance companies make decisions about premium prices in 2018. We're all fed up with partisanship and politics taking precedence over real solutions to the problems we're facing, especially in health care. My colleagues and I in the bipartisan Problem Solvers caucus have listened to experts, insurers and providers to come up with a simple straightforward revision to the ACA to make sure 20 million Americans still get affordable health care without facing exponential increases in premiums or deductibles. Read our plan here: https://schrader.house.gov/uploadedfiles/psc_health_care_proposal.pdf

The Rotary Club of Milwaukie, Oregon works to foster young leadership by recognizing them with the Rotary Youth Leadership Award. Thanks for giving young leaders and opportunity to grow, and thank you for giving me the opportunity to come speak with you today.
Thanks to everyone to came to my town hall in Clackamas County. I’m pleased to see so many people getting involved in the process. Hearing from you helps me to do my job representing you in DC!

Stayton Area Rotary took a quack at raising money for the local Scout Troop 50 this past weekend with their annual Ducky Derby. Thanks to the Rotary and everyone who donated for raising money to support the local community, it was a pleasure speaking with you all today.

The Stayton Pharmacy, LLC provides a critical service in the healthcare system for this rural community. Thank you for taking me on a tour of your business today and talking to me about ways that we can strengthen our healthcare system.

When it's 108 degrees in Salem there's no better place to beat the heat than Henningsen Cold Storage's new cooler. At a comfortable -3 degrees, this new state-of-the-art facility is Salem is all about sustainability, featuring LED lights, computer controlled refrigeration, and waste reduction systems to provide essential cold storage for local farmers with cutting-edge efficiency.

We had a great town hall with constituents in Salem last night. Thank you to everyone for getting involved and turning out. For me to be effective in Washington D.C., it’s critical that I hear from you in Oregon.

At Anderson Quality Spring Mfg they do just what the name suggests—manufacture quality springs. Started in Canby in 1993, AQS provides advanced manufacturing jobs for the community producing springs that are used in anything from motorcycles to defibrillators. It was a pleasure to visit your plant today.

Portland-area businesses and jobs are continuing to grow, and that’s due in no small part to the Portland Business Alliance. Thanks for all you do to support our local economy, and thanks for speaking with me today.
Tune in now as I join Gustavo Gutierrez-Gomez on 95.9 FM Radio Movimiento

Today I toured Detroit Lake, and through the smoke I saw a pool that’s 97% full, floating docks, and people enjoying the water. But for the last two years, times have been tough on the local economy with low water levels restricting access to the reservoir. So last summer I brought stakeholders together to help the local marinas navigate a complex multi-agency permit process that will allow them to stay afloat during the low water years. I want to thank Marion County for their ongoing commitment to this project, and Marion County Sheriff for keeping people safe on the water. And to everyone who’ll be here to see the eclipse, stay safe and have fun!

Over the last decade, our Willamette River has seen a decline in steelhead with a historic record low this year. There is a 90% likelihood that at least one population of steelhead will go extinct. Listen in as the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife discusses the problem we face and ways we can prevent our steelhead from going extinct.

What can Congress do to protect our steelhead from going extinct? My bill, the Endangered Salmon and Fisheries Predation Prevention Act, would provide tribal members and government fish managers with the means to remove predatory California sea lions from specific areas in the Columbia and Willamette Rivers where they are posing the most harm to our steelhead, salmon and sturgeon.
Had a great time vising Dallas today to meet with local Rotarians. Thanks for your commitment to this community.
Great to see the work being done at The Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde these days. Their work at the Tribal Native Plant Nursery will be an incredible resource for the region.

The racist scenes from Charlottesville last weekend were incredibly disturbing and have absolutely no place in our society. There are so few things in this world that are crystal clear, but this - neo-Nazis, white supremacists, propagators of hate and violence - is one of them. I'm disturbed that the leader of this country doesn't seem able to recognize that.

For more than 40 years Genentech has been a pioneer in the biotechnology industry. In Hillsboro, they carry out that tradition at their state-of-the-art facility where they employ hundreds of highly skilled workers from this region and create life-changing medicines for people across the world.

Today I met with officials from the City of Turner and Marion County to discuss their process for updating the FEMA flood maps and the impacts of the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP). In the wake of the 2012 floods, officials from Turner were proactive in mapping the area to ensure people and property will be safely covered for the future. We talked about what is going well and what can be improved as Congress gets to work on reauthorizing the NFIP this fall. Thank you for taking the time to walk me through what is happening in Turner and Marion County.

I visited the BIOTRONIK US campus in Lake Oswego yesterday to tour their facilities and discuss the cutting edge work they, along with Microsystems Engineering Inc. (MSEI), do in the field of medical devices as well as the many jobs they bring to our community.
Tune in now to KPAM News Talk 860 “First Edition” with Tim Hohl and Terry Travis. http://player.listenlive.co/46691
Thanks to the Keizer Rotary for your service to the community through volunteering and scholarships for students. It was a pleasure speaking with you today.

While infrastructure is a foundational cornerstone of our economy, aggregate is the physical foundation of our infrastructure. At Valley Equipment Company, Inc in Salem, they design and build the machinery that provides the aggregate for infrastructure throughout the region. Thanks for having me today to learn more about this critical industry.

While we all endure a particularly sweltering August, Swire Coca-Cola in Wilsonville is working hard to keep shelves stocked with some cool refreshments. Thanks for having me out to your distribution facility today.
Tune in to KGW-TV on Saturday at 6:30pm where I’ll be on Straight Talk with Laural Porter to talk about the protests in Charlottesville and what I’m doing to protect health care

Today, I visited the flight simulation labs at Rockwell-Collins where scientists and engineers are developing the world’s most advanced heads-up guidance systems for pilots. This incredible work is being done right here in Wilsonville, which has become a hub for some of the most cutting-edge research and development in the world.

Amazon has announced it is constructing a new facility in the Mill Creek Corporate Center. One of my early achievements in Congress was securing funding for the water infrastructure improvements that were critical to opening this area up for these opportunities. This level of investment is great for our local businesses like River Bend Sand & Gravel who are providing the aggregate and concrete. I was able to tour the site and see the project underway and look forward to seeing other companies invest in our community.

I can't believe the President is cruelly ending DACA. He didn't even have the guts to do it himself, but sent AG Sessions to do it for him. Kids who have only known this country as home now face deportation, fear and uncertainty. This is inexcusable from the President of the United States. I'll work with Congress to permanently restore the program ASAP.

Yesterday, I, along with my Oregon colleagues in the House, sent a letter to leaders in the House requesting emergency funding for wildland fire suppression. While the south faces devastating hurricanes, our home state is facing devastation of its own. Thousands of Oregonians have been evacuated, and homes and businesses have been destroyed because of the wildfires. You can read our letter calling for emergency assistance here: https://schrader.house.gov/uploadedfiles/or_delegation_letter_wildland_fire_funding_9-5-2017.pdf

Tune in as my bipartisan health care group is joined by Governors Hickenlooper of Colorado and Kasich of Ohio to discuss ways we can come together to stabilize the individual marketplace and improve Obamacare.

I joined many of my colleagues this week in calling on the Department of Homeland Security to protect the personal data of 800,000 DREAMers across our country. The young DACA recipients who have come forward and shared their personal data did so with assurances from our government. I'm not going to turn my back on them, and I'll continue to stand up for these young folks as well as our immigrant community across Oregon and the entire country. Read our letter here: https://schrader.house.gov/UploadedFiles/DHS_DACA_Letter.pdf

This morning, I spoke at the National Association of Counties about the importance of intergovernmental partnerships to our local communities in Oregon and across the country. I was joined on stage by my colleague across the aisle, Rep. Charlie Dent, to talk about ways we're working together to ensure those partnerships are as strong as they can be.

My colleagues on my Energy & Commerce Committee and I sent a letter to the CEO of Equifax today to raise the serious concerns we have and to seek more information about the massive data breach that's compromised the sensitive personal information of roughly 143 million Americans.   Read our letter: https://schrader.house.gov/UploadedFiles/Equifax.2017.09.12.Letter_to_Equifax_CEO_re_consumer_data_breach._DCCP.OI_.pdf

I took to the House floor today to bring attention to the 26 wildfires that are raging across Oregon and the hundred more  across the west. I supported funding for Super Storm Sandy, for Hurricane Harvey and I will support funding for Hurricane Irma. I’ve done this because as an American and a member of Congress it’s the right thing to do. I call on my colleagues now to also support us in the west and help us change the way we pay to fight these wildfires as we continue to face these infernos every year. This is common sense. It’s time to act.

With 193 million acres in the National Forest System, nearly 40% is vulnerable to wildfire, insects and disease, and in need of treatment. The mismanagement of these forests over the last 30 years has destroyed the health of our beautiful national forests. We need to reform our forest management practices and we need to do it now.   Enough is enough.

The North Clackamas Chamber of Commerce brining local leaders and businesses together to connect with their community. I appreciate them having me at today’s Eggs ‘N Issues this morning to talk about how to best support the community with my work in DC.

Today, I got to see firsthand the impact of the Whitewater Fire. The recent rain and snow has reduced the strength of fires, but the crews I met with are still working to prevent additional flare ups. Since it started, the Whitewater Fire Complex has burned over 14,000 acres. Last week I stood on the House Floor to call attention to the need to change how we pay for firefighting to stop depleting the funds for sustainable management. During this particularly difficult fire season, I want to thank all the men and women who have worked in Oregon’s backyard to protect our forests.
Tune in now to News Radio 1190 KEX where I’ll be taking to Mark Mason about what’s going on in Washington.

Adding to the list of innovative technologies being developed right here in the district, Garmin AT Garmin Aviation in Salem designs and manufactures advanced aviation GPS technology for navigation and air traffic control. It was a pleasure visiting the facility in Salem today and talking to more than 500 local employees about their contributions to airline safety.

Thanks to the local elected officials of the French Prairie Forum for hosting me as their keynote speaker today. This group is a critical resource for me to learn more about the needs of the district, and we had a great conversation about the issues in the North Willamette Valley.

Today, I had the honor of being joined by Rep. Linda Sánchez from California to meet with local Latino Leaders to talk about immigrants’ rights. While this administration tries to divide us instilling fear and uncertainty in Oregon’s most promising youth by ending DACA and demanding that we waste billions of taxpayer dollars on a useless wall, I stand united with our immigrant communities.

The Hispanic Chamber of Commerce works to expand the opportunities of Latinos throughout Oregon. Today, California Rep. Linda Sánchez and I met with members to talk about how Congress can best work to support and encourage Latino businesses

Today, I joined Rep. Linda Sánchez and Oregon State Representative Teresa Alonso Leon to meet with student leaders from the five high schools in the Woodburn School District where we talked about their current political concerns and answer questions. These students have shown incredible leadership, and I can’t wait to see what they’ll bring to the community.

Operating in 19 states, Knife River Corporation is one of the largest construction materials and contracting companies in the United States. The material from this transloading station in Salem will be used to pave the stretch of I-5 outside Woodburn. And, Knife River has managed to cut down on their oil use by 50 percent with the use of recycled oil from old roads and roof shingles.

For families, comprehensive, accessible, and affordable healthcare services are essential. I’m happy to see the new Lancaster Family Health Center in Salem aiming to provide just this, offering a full range of services from chronic illness, to dental care. Thanks for helping to build a healthier community in Salem.

Community Health Centers (CHCs) are often the only available primary care facilities in our rural communities throughout Oregon and across the country. In Oregon alone, they provide over one million patient visits each year. For months now, I’ve been calling on leadership to reauthorize funding for CHCs in a bipartisan way. Unless Congress acts at the end of this week, funding to support these centers will expire. We shouldn't be putting access to care for hundreds of thousands of Oregonians in jeopardy. Let's get our priorities in line now, before it's too late.

This President has based his whole career on showmanship and publicity stunts, but what he just pulled - ending cost lowering payments for the individual health insurance exchange - is more than a stunt: it’s the worst kind of spite. The only consequence of ending these payments is a bottomed out individual marketplace, making insurance unaffordable for millions of Americans. There is absolutely no benefit to anyone, no practical or necessary reason for ending these payments, which are already fully paid for, other than to deliberately and actively take away health care. It is time for Congress to reassert itself and legislate a bipartisan solution for millions of Americans. Read my full statement: https://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390950

Business in the greater Portland area is booming, and that is in no small part to the advocacy of the Westside Economic Alliance. It was a pleasure speaking with you today about my work in Congress and how it affects our businesses at home.
There are so many great projects happening in Lake Oswego right now. Thanks to Mayor Studebaker for taking me out to see new additions in the community.

This morning I had the opportunity to join Douglas McKay High School's Principal Schoepper for a “day in the life.” Our principals take on responsibility for their entire school and each of its students, a responsibility they never leave at the office. I want to thank Principal Schoepper—and all of our school principals—for working hard to give their students a bright future. #thankaprincipal

Congrats to the Salem (Or.) Rotary Club for pulling off their first Salem Triathlon. Salem Rotary Club is always coming up with new ways to serve the community, and it was a pleasure speaking with them today.
Had a great meeting with the Clackamas County Business Alliance this morning to talk about what’s happening in Washington and how it’s affecting business here at home.

Talking with high school students about government and how they can serve the community is always inspiring, and it gives me hope for the future. Thanks to the students at Oregon City High School for meeting with me today.
I'm calling on my colleagues to allow a vote on, and pass, a clean DREAM Act that will recognize Dreamers across the country, like Diana, as equal member of our community.

As co-chair of the House Paper and Packaging Caucus, I took to the House floor this week to highlight National Forest Products Week. This industry produces products in 45 states and employs over 900,000 men and women. Oregon is home to over 174 wood products, paper, and packaging manufacturing facilities that make nearly $11 billion in products annually and contribute over $2 billion to our state and local economies. We’re fortunate to have the renewable natural resources and the domestic manufacturing to be able to produce the paper and packaging, tissue, and wood products that are central to modern life and a modern economy.

Make sure you and your family have health insurance next year! Open enrollment for 2018 begins TODAY and is only half as long as years past. Whether you already get coverage through the exchange and want to make a change to your plan, or you're looking to get covered for the first time, December 15th is a hard deadline for everyone, so don't wait! Sign up at: healthcare.oregon.gov

I took to the House floor this week to share Juan’s story. Juan, who suffers from cerebral palsy and was unable to walk for the first 15 years of his life, is an Oregon Dreamer. We need to pass a clean Dream Act to recognize DACA recipients like Juan as equal members of our communities.

This morning I met with a group of specialty crop farmers to talk about their priorities for the upcoming 2018 Farm Bill. Our specialty crop farmers are a critical part of Oregon’s rural economy, and Oregon has more farmland dedicated to nursery production, cut Christmas trees, and filberts than anywhere else in the country. So, today I talked with these farmers about how we can create a Farm Bill to expand market access for their crops, increase research dollars for their products, and protect them from natural disasters. I want to thank all the aggies who took the time away from their farm to speak with me today.

I grew strawberries on my farm in Canby where my son now grows hops, and I know how important it is to all the family farms in Oregon that we get this right. Today I met with local Oregon Farm Bureau members to talk about how I can be a strong voice for Oregon's agricultural communities during 2018 Farm Bill debate. Thanks to everyone for talking with me about what works, what doesn’t, and what I can do to help.

When our veterans come home, we make a promise to take care of them. In Oregon, we work hard to make that a reality, but there is always more that we can do. I gathered local Veterans Service Officers, local community leaders, and representatives from the Oregon Department of Veterans Affairs to talk about how all levels of government can work together to provide our veterans with the care and respect that they deserve. #VeteransDay

I’ve received a number of calls this week on net neutrality, and ahead of the FCC’s slated vote for December 14th, I wanted to make sure everyone knows where I stand. As a long-time supporter of net neutrality, I am incredibly disappointed with Chairman Pai’s decision to roll back net neutrality rules with no plan to ensure equal and open access to the internet for all Oregonians. Throughout this process it’s become abundantly clear that the public is overwhelmingly in support of enforceable protections to ensure an open internet. And I am, too. Read my full statement here: https://schrader.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=390978
NA

Each year I have the honor and privilege of nominating Oregon's brightest students to our military service academies. This year will mark the second year I have organized a Service Academy Information Day in hopes of providing motivated high school students from Oregon’s Fifth Congressional District an opportunity to learn about our nations' service academies. The Service Academy Information Day will be Saturday, March 4, 2017 at Portland Community College, Sylvania Campus from 9:00 am to 11:00 am.  I have invited admission liaisons from the U.S. Military Academy, U.S. Naval Academy, U.S. Air Force Academy, U.S. Coast Guard Academy, and U.S. Merchant Marine Academy to answer any questions students may have about the admission process.  Congressional staffers from the offices of Senators Wyden and Merkley, and Represtatives Blumenauer and Bonamici will also be available to answer questions about their nomination process.  Portland Community College, Sylvania Campus Amo DeBernardis College Center 12000 SW 49th Ave, Portland, OR 97219  We hope to see you there!
